isis.stitle: 7.3 Liter Diesel Engine Service (1991) - INJECTION PUMP, NOZZLES, FUEL FILTER, SUPPLY PUMP AND GLOW PLUGS - FUEL INJECTION NOZZLES - FLAT LAPPING PROCEDURES

svcproc.title: FLAT LAPPING PROCEDURES

note.para: Use lapping block set SE2250. Obtain directly from: Bacharach, Inc., 625 Alpha Drive, Pittsburgh, PA 15238.

step1.para: Prepare the lapping blocks for use by washing them in fuel oil and using a bristle brush. Dry off with filtered compressed air. DO NOT USE WIPING RAGS.
Mix a small amount of lapping compound (1000 grit) into a thin paste using calibrating fluid.

note.para: In some areas, prepared lapping compound can be obtained in small tubes.

step1.para: Apply a very small amount of lapping compound (well spread out) to the lapped side of the block. Keep this amount at a minimum to obtain the best results.

note.para: Blocks that are grooved on both sides are generally marked to indicate which side is the lapped surface.

step1.para: The part to be lapped should be placed upon the lapping block and moved about in a figure eight pattern.

svcproc.para:
To equalize the wear in the lapping block, the series of figure eight strokes should start at one side and progress across the block as shown in Figure 9.53
.

step1.para: Apply only enough pressure to keep the part flat on the block. After four or five "passes", lift the part off the block and clean the compound off by rubbing the part across a clean sheet of paper placed on a flat surface. (Avoid excessive lapping.) If the surface of the lapped part does not appear uniform in reflected light or if there are any depressions around the sealing surfaces, repeat the lapping procedure above (see Note).

note.para: When the lapping process does not remove depressions or provide good sealing surfaces, the component must be replaced with a new one.

step1.para: Perform the last step, DRY LAPPING, which produces a mirror-like finish and provides an excellent sealing surface. Proceed as follows:

step2.para: Clean the block in the same manner as described earlier and dry with filtered compressed air. The block used MUST BE FREE OF ANY LAPPING COMPOUND.

Place the part to be lapped on the block surface and move it about in a figure eight pattern across the whole area of the block ( Figure 9.54
). Make four or five passes, then inspect the finish before repeating (if necessary).
Apply only enough pressure to keep the part flat on the block.

note.para: Do not handle parts on the lapped surfaces as corrosion will appear in the are as touched.

important.para: KEEP THE LAPPING BLOCKS COVERED WHEN NOT BEING USED, TO KEEP DUST OR OTHER FOREIGN MATTER FROM THE SURFACE.
